ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I haven't studied the post-communist region through a theoretical approach before, but only through a historical approach. This course was quite helpful in synthesizing some of the political theories I learned in my undergraduate career and using them to gain valuable insight in the region.

This course was invaluable in understanding the evolution of Post-soviet studies in political science. A well-designed course with a reading list that I am ever thankful for, Hanson offered useful insights into current and past debates about area studies, rational choice theory, institutionalism, and more.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The syllabus was very organized and the readings each week were very informative and led to some great class discussions. I would have perhaps preferred to focus on maybe Central Asia or the Visegrad countries more, but I understand that time was a definite hindrance.
A longer final paper with the chance to workshop ideas in class would have made the final output of the class more relevant to doctoral students' ongoing research.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to anyone studying the Eastern European region.
Highly! Anyone interested in post-communism in Eastern Europe or institutional development and decline should take this course.
